title: Rio Ferdinand adamant Ole Gunnar Solskjaer will not be sacked by Man Utd
text:

Rio Ferdinand is confident Manchester United will not sack Ole Gunnar Solskjaer any time soon.

Solskjaer has overseen United's worst start to a season for 30 years, with the Red Devils languishing in 12th place in the Premier League.

The manager's reign hit a new low with defeat at Newcastle on Sunday, which followed a 0-0 draw away to AZ Alkmaar in the Europa League last week.

United have won just two of their eight league games so far this season, and are only two points off the relegation zone.

While Solskjaer initially oversaw a big upturn in results when he took over on an interim basis after Jose Mourinho was sacked last December, United's form has dipped alarmingly since he was appointed on a permanent basis in March.

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

But former United defender Ferdinand says the club's board never expected the Norwegian to revitalise the club's fortunes overnight - and insists there will be no knee-jerk decision to sack him.

"There's no way the club would have thought this would be rosy straight away, they're not naive enough to think that it was going to be a situation where he just changes it overnight," he told talkSPORT.

"This is definitely something where there is going to be early pain, there is going to be a situation where the results are not going to go our way, especially with the new recruitment that they've started to go with younger players.

"That's why I don't see there being a change straight away, I'd be very surprised if I wake up, open a paper or an app and see that he has gone so quickly."

(Image: BT Sports)

United have been short of goals after they did not replace Romelu Lukaku or Alexis Sanchez in the summer - while their forward line was also hit by injuries to Marcus Rashford and Anthony Martial recently.

The summer also saw a shift in United's recruitment strategy with the club moving away from star names towards bringing in young players, with Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Harry Maguire and Daniel James all signing.

And with players like 18-year-old Mason Greenwood also having been fast-tracked into the first team, Ferdinand says United's new focus on youth must be taken into account when assessing Solskjaer's time in the hotseat.

The former centre-half said: "They've got some good young ones, I don't think they expected what they have got from Daniel James so early, he's been very good and probably their most influential so far.

(Image: Manchester United via Getty Imag)

"What does that say about the squad? When you're buying someone from Swansea who was probably brought as someone who could flourish at a later date, who has now been forced into the forefront as the main man in the team at the moment.

"That says where United are at this minute and I think time is something that is needed. It's not afforded to too many people in the game at the moment.

"Ole probably needs another window to get more people in, shuffle the pack and get more out, then you can really start to judge him on that."
description: Former Red Devils defender says club didn't expect overnight success and won't rush to get rid of manager
